overview.short: Leuconostoc species are Gram-positive lactic acid bacteria, typically appearing as cocci or short coccobacilli, that are catalase-negative, non-motile, and heterofermentative (often producing gas from glucose).
overview.clinical_context: Most commonly associated with food and environmental sources; can cause opportunistic infections in immunocompromised patients and is notable for intrinsic vancomycin resistance.

field_notes.Shape: Often reported as cocci in pairs/short chains; may appear coccobacillary depending on growth conditions and smear quality.
field_notes.Gas Production: Heterofermentative metabolism commonly produces CO2 from glucose fermentation.
field_notes.Catalase: Typically negative; weak pseudocatalase reactions can occur in some lactic acid bacteria depending on medium and heme availability.

key_differentiators.notes: Catalase negativity supports lactic acid bacteria rather than staphylococci/micrococci.
Gas from glucose supports heterofermentative LAB such as Leuconostoc.
Enterococci commonly tolerate higher NaCl; Leuconostoc typically does not.

common_confusions.reason: Catalase-negative Gram-positive cocci can resemble viridans streptococci on primary culture.
Catalase-negative Gram-positive cocci overlap clinically; enterococci often show stronger bile-esculin positivity and higher salt tolerance.
Both are lactic acid bacteria; morphology differs but can be ambiguous if described broadly.

when_to_question_identification: Strong growth in >=6% NaCl suggests Enterococcus rather than Leuconostoc.
Consistent beta haemolysis is atypical and suggests alternative genera.
Oxidase or catalase positivity argues against Leuconostoc.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Leuconostoc is characteristically intrinsically resistant, which can support genus-level suspicion in clinical contexts.
Reliable genus/species identification among lactic acid bacteria with overlapping biochemical patterns.
Supports species-level separation within Leuconostoc when required.
